clusters.title: US admiral to brief lawmakers as bipartisan scrutiny grows over boat strike
clusters.neutral_headline: US Navy Admiral Faces Scrutiny Over Caribbean Boat Strike

items.title: US admiral to brief lawmakers as bipartisan scrutiny grows over boat strike
items.standfirst: Questions mount over US attack in Caribbean Sea that killed survivors on boat allegedly carrying drugs A US navy admiral will provide a classified briefing to lawmakers overseeing the military on Thursday as they investigate a US attack on a boat in the Caribbean Sea allegedly carrying drugs that included a second strike that killed any survivors.The White House press secretary, Karoline Leavitt, on Monday said the second strike was carried out “in self-defence” and in accordance with laws governing armed conflict. Continue reading...
items.content: Questions mount over US attack in Caribbean Sea that killed survivors on boat allegedly carrying drugs A US navy admiral will provide a classified briefing to lawmakers overseeing the military on Thursday as they investigate a US attack on a boat in the Caribbean Sea allegedly carrying drugs that included a second strike that killed any survivors.The White House press secretary, Karoline Leavitt, on Monday said the second strike was carried out “in self-defence” and in accordance with laws governing armed conflict. Continue reading...

items.title: US confirms two strikes ordered on boat
items.standfirst: Washington is putting further pressure on Venezuela with a major naval build up in the Caribbean. The US military has already struck at least 19 suspected drug vessels since September. The White House on Monday defended a US admiral's decision to conduct multiple strikes on one such vessel. Reports said Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth ordered that everyone be killed. Morgan Ayre reports.
items.content: Washington is putting further pressure on Venezuela with a major naval build up in the Caribbean. The US military has already struck at least 19 suspected drug vessels since September. The White House on Monday defended a US admiral's decision to conduct multiple strikes on one such vessel. Reports said Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth ordered that everyone be killed. Morgan Ayre reports.

items.title: National Guard shooting suspect spent weeks in isolation, 2024 emails say
items.standfirst: According to 2024 emails obtained by CBS News, Rahmanullah Lakanwal had been struggling to hold a job and had not been doing well mentally for more than a year.
items.content: According to 2024 emails obtained by CBS News, Rahmanullah Lakanwal had been struggling to hold a job and had not been doing well mentally for more than a year.

items.title: New details about National Guard shooting suspect's mental health
items.standfirst: CBS News has learned new details about the suspect accused of shooting two West Virginia National Guard members in Washington, D.C. As Nicole Sganga reports, Rahmanullah Lakanwal's former immigration case worker said that his mental condition deteriorated in recent years.
items.content: CBS News has learned new details about the suspect accused of shooting two West Virginia National Guard members in Washington, D.C. As Nicole Sganga reports, Rahmanullah Lakanwal's former immigration case worker said that his mental condition deteriorated in recent years.

items.title: Second strike on alleged drug boat was "war crime," says former Defense Secretary Leon Panetta
items.standfirst: The White House said that a U.S. attack on an alleged drug boat in September included more than one strike on the vessel, seemingly confirming a Washington Post report that the U.S. targeted the boat for a second time to take out survivors of the initial attack. Former Defense Secretary Leon Panetta discussed the strikes with "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson.
items.content: The White House said that a U.S. attack on an alleged drug boat in September included more than one strike on the vessel, seemingly confirming a Washington Post report that the U.S. targeted the boat for a second time to take out survivors of the initial attack. Former Defense Secretary Leon Panetta discussed the strikes with "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson.

items.title: How the Trump administration's account of boat strike has evolved
items.standfirst: The U.S. military's early September strike on an alleged Venezuelan drug boat has drawn new scrutiny as the White House confirmed that the vessel was struck twice.
items.content: The U.S. military's early September strike on an alleged Venezuelan drug boat has drawn new scrutiny as the White House confirmed that the vessel was struck twice.

items.title: White House confirms follow-up strike on alleged drug boat

items.content: White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said the commander of a September operation "worked well within his authority and the law" when ordering a follow-on strike.

items.title: Trump officials meet to discuss Venezuela amid scrutiny of second strike on alleged drug boat
items.standfirst: The President Trump convened a meeting of his national security team to talk about Venezuela and what the U.S. will do next amid heightened tensions in the region. It comes amid fresh scrutiny of one of the 21 U.S. strikes on alleged drug boats. Weijia Jiang reports, then "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson speaks about the issue with former Defense Secretary Leon Panetta.
items.content: The President Trump convened a meeting of his national security team to talk about Venezuela and what the U.S. will do next amid heightened tensions in the region. It comes amid fresh scrutiny of one of the 21 U.S. strikes on alleged drug boats. Weijia Jiang reports, then "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson speaks about the issue with former Defense Secretary Leon Panetta.

items.content: The shooting raised questions about whether the government missed any red flags about the alleged attacker, 29-year-old Afghan national Rahmanullah Lakanwal.

items.title: White House confirms a second strike was ordered on an alleged drug boat
items.standfirst: White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said Navy Adm. Frank M. Bradley ordered the subsequent strike on an alleged drug boat in the Caribbean.
items.content: White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said Navy Adm. Frank M. Bradley ordered the subsequent strike on an alleged drug boat in the Caribbean.

The White House stated the second strike was in self-defense, following armed conflict laws.
Reports indicate Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth ordered the elimination of all survivors.
Admiral Frank Bradley, head of USSOCOM, authorized the second strike on the vessel.
The strike has raised questions about legality, according to various news sources.

clusters.title: Witkoff in Moscow for talks as Putin claims to have taken key Ukrainian city
clusters.neutral_headline: US Envoy in Moscow for Ukraine Peace Talks with Putin

items.title: Witkoff in Moscow for talks as Putin claims to have taken key Ukrainian city
items.standfirst: Trump’s special envoy lands in Russia as Putin hails ‘important’ capture of Pokrovsk, although this is disputed by KyivRussia-Ukraine war – latest news updatesVladimir Putin has claimed Russian forces have taken control of the strategic city of Pokrovsk in Ukraine, as he sought to project confidence before a key meeting on Tuesday with a US delegation to discuss a possible peace deal to end the war.Dressed in military fatigues during a visit to a command centre on Monday evening, the Russian president hailed what he called the “important” capture of Pokrovsk – once a major logistical hub for the Ukrainian army – though Ukrainian officials later disputed the claim. Continue reading...
items.content: Trump’s special envoy lands in Russia as Putin hails ‘important’ capture of Pokrovsk, although this is disputed by KyivRussia-Ukraine war – latest news updatesVladimir Putin has claimed Russian forces have taken control of the strategic city of Pokrovsk in Ukraine, as he sought to project confidence before a key meeting on Tuesday with a US delegation to discuss a possible peace deal to end the war.Dressed in military fatigues during a visit to a command centre on Monday evening, the Russian president hailed what he called the “important” capture of Pokrovsk – once a major logistical hub for the Ukrainian army – though Ukrainian officials later disputed the claim. Continue reading...

items.title: U.S. envoy in Moscow for high-stakes Ukraine peace talks with Putin
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump’s special envoy is meeting Russian President Vladimir Putin Tuesday fortalks that Washington hopes will convince the Kremlin to end his war in Ukraine.
items.content: President Donald Trump’s special envoy is meeting Russian President Vladimir Putin Tuesday fortalks that Washington hopes will convince the Kremlin to end his war in Ukraine.

items.title: Putin and Trump's envoy set for key Ukraine talks in Moscow
items.standfirst: Steve Witkoff will hold talks at the Kremlin, after the White House said it was "optimistic" about a breakthrough.
items.content: Steve Witkoff will hold talks at the Kremlin, after the White House said it was "optimistic" about a breakthrough.

items.title: Witkoff and Kushner to meet Putin in Moscow to discuss an end to the Ukraine war
items.standfirst: US envoy Steve Witkoff and Russian President Vladimir Putin are expected to hold talks in Moscow on Tuesday to discuss the Trump administration's controversial proposal to end the war in Ukraine.
items.content: US envoy Steve Witkoff and Russian President Vladimir Putin are expected to hold talks in Moscow on Tuesday to discuss the Trump administration's controversial proposal to end the war in Ukraine.

items.title: Russia claims control of Pokrovsk
items.standfirst: President Vladimir Putin has hailed what his commanders told him was the full Russian capture of the city of Pokrovsk in eastern Ukraine as an important victory after a prolonged campaign, saying it would help Moscow fulfil its wider war aims. There was no immediate comment from Ukraine, which has said in recent weeks it was holding back Russian forces in the north of the city.
items.content: President Vladimir Putin has hailed what his commanders told him was the full Russian capture of the city of Pokrovsk in eastern Ukraine as an important victory after a prolonged campaign, saying it would help Moscow fulfil its wider war aims. There was no immediate comment from Ukraine, which has said in recent weeks it was holding back Russian forces in the north of the city.

items.title: Live: Russia claims control of Pokrovsk, Ukraine says still holds part of city
items.standfirst: President Vladimir Putin on Tuesday hailed reports from military commanders claiming Russian forces had taken full control of the northern Ukrainian city of Pokrovsk. The Ukraine military, however, said it was still holding the northern part of the strategic city, and that fighting is still ongoing. The contradicting reports come as Donald Trump’s special peace envoy is due to meet Putin in Moscow to discuss a proposal to end the war in Ukraine. Follow our liveblog for all the latest news.
items.content: President Vladimir Putin on Tuesday hailed reports from military commanders claiming Russian forces had taken full control of the northern Ukrainian city of Pokrovsk. The Ukraine military, however, said it was still holding the northern part of the strategic city, and that fighting is still ongoing. The contradicting reports come as Donald Trump’s special peace envoy is due to meet Putin in Moscow to discuss a proposal to end the war in Ukraine. Follow our liveblog for all the latest news.

items.title: Kushner and Witkoff to meet with Putin in Moscow

items.content: President Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, and special envoy Steve Witkoff are meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin Tuesday to discuss the war in Ukraine.

items.title: Ukraine warns 'tough issues' remain in peace talks as U.S. team heads to Russia

items.content: President Donald Trump says there's a “good chance” for a peace deal between Russia and Ukraine, but his negotiators have hard work ahead — they now head to the Kremlin and still need to iron out key details with Kyiv

clusters.title: Plea deal with son of drug kingpin 'El Chapo' details abduction of legendary Sinaloa capo
clusters.neutral_headline: Son of "El Chapo" Pleads Guilty to US Drug Charges

items.title: Plea deal with son of drug kingpin 'El Chapo' details abduction of legendary Sinaloa capo
items.standfirst: Joaquín Guzmán López, the 39-year-old son of former Sinaloa cartel kingpin Joaquín "El Chapo" Guzmán, pleaded guilty to two counts of drug trafficking and continuing criminal enterprise in federal court in Chicago.
items.content: Joaquín Guzmán López, the 39-year-old son of former Sinaloa cartel kingpin Joaquín "El Chapo" Guzmán, pleaded guilty to two counts of drug trafficking and continuing criminal enterprise in federal court in Chicago.(Image credit: US Department of State)

items.title: Son of Mexican drug lord 'El Chapo' pleads guilty to narcotics trafficking
items.standfirst: Joaquin Guzman Lopez, a son of jailed Mexican drug lord Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman, pleaded guilty in Chicago on Monday to narcotics trafficking and running a criminal enterprise, US media reported. He had initially denied the charges after his July 2024 arrest in Texas.
items.content: Joaquin Guzman Lopez, a son of jailed Mexican drug lord Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman, pleaded guilty in Chicago on Monday to narcotics trafficking and running a criminal enterprise, US media reported. He had initially denied the charges after his July 2024 arrest in Texas.

items.title: El Chapo’s son pleads guilty in US drug case, cuts deal with prosecutors
items.standfirst: Joaquin Guzman Lopez pleads guilty to drug trafficking and to kidnapping an individual believed to be 'El Mayo' Zambada.
items.content: Joaquin Guzman Lopez pleads guilty to drug trafficking and to kidnapping an individual believed to be 'El Mayo' Zambada.

items.title: Drug lord El Chapo's son pleads guilty in US drug trafficking case
items.standfirst: Joaquín Guzmán López's guilty plea comes after US prosecutors pledged last May to not pursue the death penalty against him.
items.content: Joaquín Guzmán López's guilty plea comes after US prosecutors pledged last May to not pursue the death penalty against him.

items.title: Son of "El Chapo" pleads guilty to U.S. drug trafficking charges
items.standfirst: As part of the plea deal, Joaquin Guzman Lopez admitted to helping oversee the production and smuggling of large quantities of cocaine, heroin, methamphetamine, marijuana and fentanyl into the U.S.
items.content: As part of the plea deal, Joaquin Guzman Lopez admitted to helping oversee the production and smuggling of large quantities of cocaine, heroin, methamphetamine, marijuana and fentanyl into the U.S.

ai_summary: Joaquin Guzman Lopez pleaded guilty to drug trafficking charges in Chicago.
He admitted to overseeing the production and smuggling of drugs into the US.
The plea deal involves cooperation with prosecutors and a reduced sentence.
Guzman Lopez was arrested in Texas in July 2024, initially denying charges.
He is the son of former Sinaloa cartel kingpin Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman.

clusters.title: Hong Kong responds to disaster differently from Beijing – but the gulf is narrowing
clusters.neutral_headline: Hong Kong Orders Investigation into Deadly Fire

items.title: Hong Kong responds to disaster differently from Beijing – but the gulf is narrowing
items.standfirst: Independent inquiry into fire and media questions to leader would not happen in mainland China, but crackdown on dissent has begunAs Hong Kong mourns the victims of its worst fire in decades, the response to the disaster reveals the ways in which the semi-autonomous city retains differences from mainland China – and how some of those differences are being eroded.Hong Kong’s leader, John Lee, announced on Tuesday the creation of an “independent committee” to investigate the blaze, which killed 151 people at the Wang Fuk Court apartment complex in Hong Kong’s New Territories. Continue reading...
items.content: Independent inquiry into fire and media questions to leader would not happen in mainland China, but crackdown on dissent has begunAs Hong Kong mourns the victims of its worst fire in decades, the response to the disaster reveals the ways in which the semi-autonomous city retains differences from mainland China – and how some of those differences are being eroded.Hong Kong’s leader, John Lee, announced on Tuesday the creation of an “independent committee” to investigate the blaze, which killed 151 people at the Wang Fuk Court apartment complex in Hong Kong’s New Territories. Continue reading...

items.title: Hong Kong to start independent inquiry into deadly fire as public pressure mounts
items.standfirst: Hong Kong will set up an independent committee of inquiry headed by a judge to determine the cause of a deadly apartment block fire that shocked the city, and to make recommendations to prevent a similar tragedy from happening again, its leader said Tuesday.
items.content: Hong Kong will set up an independent committee of inquiry headed by a judge to determine the cause of a deadly apartment block fire that shocked the city, and to make recommendations to prevent a similar tragedy from happening again, its leader said Tuesday.

items.title: Hong Kong leader orders independent investigation into fire that killed 151
items.standfirst: Hong Kong's Chief Executive John Lee says committee to be led by a judge and will identify the causes of deadly blaze.
items.content: Hong Kong's Chief Executive John Lee says committee to be led by a judge and will identify the causes of deadly blaze.

items.title: Hong Kong leader orders investigation into deadly fire that killed 151
items.standfirst: The fire is the deadliest the city has seen in more than 70 years.
items.content: The fire is the deadliest the city has seen in more than 70 years.

items.title: Hong Kong leader orders probe into deadly blaze that killed 151
items.standfirst: Hong Kong’s leader on Tuesday announced a judge-led independent committee to investigate last week’s apartment blaze that killed 151 people. Officials said the city’s worst fire in decades spread rapidly through exterior scaffolding netting that failed to meet fire-resistance standards and did not prevent the flames from spreading.
items.content: Hong Kong’s leader on Tuesday announced a judge-led independent committee to investigate last week’s apartment blaze that killed 151 people. Officials said the city’s worst fire in decades spread rapidly through exterior scaffolding netting that failed to meet fire-resistance standards and did not prevent the flames from spreading.

ai_summary: Hong Kong will launch an independent inquiry into a deadly apartment fire.
The fire killed 151 people at the Wang Fuk Court apartment complex.
The investigation will be led by a judge to determine the fire's cause.
The fire is the deadliest in Hong Kong in over seventy years.
The inquiry aims to prevent similar tragedies in the future.

clusters.title: Iranian director given jail sentence while on trip to collect US awards
clusters.neutral_headline: Iran sentences awardwinning director Jafar Panahi 'in abstentia' to one year in prison

items.title: Iranian director given jail sentence while on trip to collect US awards
items.standfirst: Jafar Panahi gets a one-year sentence in his absence for "propaganda activities" against the Iranian system.
items.content: Jafar Panahi gets a one-year sentence in his absence for "propaganda activities" against the Iranian system.

items.title: Iran sentences awardwinning director Jafar Panahi 'in abstentia' to one year in prison
items.standfirst: Iran has sentenced Palme d'Or-winning filmmaker Jafar Panahi in absentia to one year in prison and imposed a two-year travel ban for alleged “propaganda activities,” his lawyer said on Monday. The ruling also bars him from joining political or social groups, and his legal team plans to appeal.
items.content: Iran has sentenced Palme d'Or-winning filmmaker Jafar Panahi in absentia to one year in prison and imposed a two-year travel ban for alleged “propaganda activities,” his lawyer said on Monday. The ruling also bars him from joining political or social groups, and his legal team plans to appeal.

items.title: Iran sentences award-winning director Jafar Panahi to year in prison for ‘propaganda activities’
items.standfirst: Iranian film-maker won Cannes film festival’s Palme D’Or prize earlier this year for It Was Just an AccidentIran has sentenced the Palme d’Or-winning film-maker Jafar Panahi in absentia to one year in prison and a travel ban over “propaganda activities” against the country.The sentence includes a two-year ban on leaving Iran and prohibition of Panahi from membership of any political or social groups, his lawyer Mostafa Nili said, adding that they would file an appeal. Continue reading...
items.content: Iranian film-maker won Cannes film festival’s Palme D’Or prize earlier this year for It Was Just an AccidentIran has sentenced the Palme d’Or-winning film-maker Jafar Panahi in absentia to one year in prison and a travel ban over “propaganda activities” against the country.The sentence includes a two-year ban on leaving Iran and prohibition of Panahi from membership of any political or social groups, his lawyer Mostafa Nili said, adding that they would file an appeal. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Iran sentenced Jafar Panahi to one year in prison in absentia.
The sentence includes a two-year travel ban for "propaganda activities."
Panahi is also banned from joining political or social groups.
The ruling stems from his alleged "propaganda activities" against Iran.
Panahi won the Palme d'Or at Cannes earlier this year.

clusters.title: Trump accuses Honduras of ‘trying to change’ outcome of presidential vote
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Accuses Honduras of Trying to Change Election Outcome

items.title: Trump accuses Honduras of ‘trying to change’ outcome of presidential vote
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Monday accused Honduras election officials of “trying to change” the outcome of the presidential vote after the race was too close to call in the digital preliminary results, and the remaining votes are being counted by hand. Trump, who has thrown his weight behind the conservative candidate, warned there will be “hell to pay” if he considers the final results manipulated.
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Monday accused Honduras election officials of “trying to change” the outcome of the presidential vote after the race was too close to call in the digital preliminary results, and the remaining votes are being counted by hand. Trump, who has thrown his weight behind the conservative candidate, warned there will be “hell to pay” if he considers the final results manipulated.

items.title: Trump Threatens 'Hell To Pay' as Honduras Election Count Continues
items.standfirst: Trump backs the conservative candidate as a good ally to fight 'narcocommunists.'
items.content: Trump backs the conservative candidate as a good ally to fight 'narcocommunists.'

ai_summary: Donald Trump accused Honduras of trying to change the election outcome.
Trump supports the conservative candidate in Honduras.
He warned of consequences if the final results are manipulated.
The election results are still being counted by hand.
Trump has thrown his weight behind the conservative candidate.

items.title: Trump Administration Locks In Zero Tariffs On UK Pharmaceuticals As NHS To Pay More For US Drugs
items.standfirst: The UK and the U.S. have reached a landmark agreement to eliminate tariffs on British pharmaceutical products being exported to America. items.content: The UK and the U.S. have reached a landmark agreement to eliminate tariffs on British pharmaceutical products being exported to America. items.title: NHS to pay 25% more for innovative drugs after UK–US zero-tariff deal
items.standfirst: Agreement could cost NHS an extra £3bn a year, industry sources estimateThe UK has agreed to pay 25% more for new medicines by 2035 as part of a US-UK drug pricing deal that will cost an estimated additional £3bn a year.The transatlantic agreement will also see the health service in England, which currently spends £14.4bn a year on innovative therapies, double the percentage of GDP it allocates to buying such products, from 0.3% to 0.6% over the next decade. Continue reading...
items.content: Agreement could cost NHS an extra £3bn a year, industry sources estimateThe UK has agreed to pay 25% more for new medicines by 2035 as part of a US-UK drug pricing deal that will cost an estimated additional £3bn a year.The transatlantic agreement will also see the health service in England, which currently spends £14.4bn a year on innovative therapies, double the percentage of GDP it allocates to buying such products, from 0.3% to 0.6% over the next decade. Continue reading...

The UK and US reached an agreement to eliminate tariffs on pharmaceuticals.
The deal could cost the NHS an extra £3 billion per year.
The NHS will double the percentage of GDP spent on innovative drugs.
The agreement will adjust prices under the UK-US pharma deal.

clusters.title: Asia floods death toll tops 1,160 as troops aid survivors

items.title: Asia floods death toll tops 1,160 as troops aid survivors
items.standfirst: The toll in deadly flooding and landslides across parts of Asia climbed past 1,160 on Monday as hardest-hit Sri Lanka and Indonesia deployed military personnel to help survivors. Speaking with FRANCE 24's Mark Owen, Dr Akshay Deoras, Research Scientist at the National Centre for Atmospheric Science at the University of Reading, says that 'the focus has to shift from talking about climate change to really dealing with it on the ground and keep people away from vulnerable areas'.
items.content: The toll in deadly flooding and landslides across parts of Asia climbed past 1,160 on Monday as hardest-hit Sri Lanka and Indonesia deployed military personnel to help survivors. Speaking with FRANCE 24's Mark Owen, Dr Akshay Deoras, Research Scientist at the National Centre for Atmospheric Science at the University of Reading, says that 'the focus has to shift from talking about climate change to really dealing with it on the ground and keep people away from vulnerable areas'.

items.title: Sri Lanka and Indonesia deploy militaries as Asia floods death toll passes 1,100
items.standfirst: Millions of people affected by torrential rainfall in Sri Lanka and large parts of Indonesia’s Sumatra, southern Thailand and northern MalaysiaHow cyclones and monsoon rains combined to devastate parts of Asia – visual guideSri Lanka and Indonesia have deployed military personnel as they race to help victims of devastating flooding that has killed more than 1,100 people across four countries in Asia.Millions of people have been affected by a combination of tropical cyclones and heavy monsoon rains in Sri Lanka, parts of Indonesia’s Sumatra, Thailand and Malaysia in recent days. Continue reading...

items.title: Death toll passes 1,100 in devastating floods across Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Malaysia and Thailand – as it happened
items.standfirst: This blog is now closed.Full report: Sri Lanka and Indonesia deploy militaries as Asia floods death toll passes 1,100How cyclones and monsoon rains combined to devastate parts of Asia – visual guideCyclone Ditwah, which unleashed catastrophic flooding and landslides across Sri Lanka, has brought heavy rain to India’s southern state of Tamil Nadu.The storm, now about 30 miles off the coast of the city of Chennai, the state capital, has weakened into a “deep depression”, according to weather officials, who expect it to weaken even further across the day. Continue reading...

items.title: Sri Lanka braced for more damage after torrential rain kills hundreds across Asia
items.standfirst: Meanwhile, Iran grapples with one of worst droughts and temperatures fall 10C below normal in USMore heavy rainfall is expected in Sri Lanka in the coming days, likely resulting in further damage across the country. It comes after torrential rainfall in south-east Asia triggered catastrophic flash floods and landslides that have affected millions, killing more than 300 people in Indonesia and 160 in Thailand, with hundreds more still missing.Parts of North Sumatra, Indonesia, were hit with rainfall totals of 800mm over four days, with other areas also experiencing heavy rainfall. Continue reading...
items.content: Meanwhile, Iran grapples with one of worst droughts and temperatures fall 10C below normal in USMore heavy rainfall is expected in Sri Lanka in the coming days, likely resulting in further damage across the country. Continue reading...

Sri Lanka and Indonesia are deploying military personnel for aid.
The affected countries include Sri Lanka, Indonesia, Thailand, and Malaysia.
Heavy rainfall and cyclones have contributed to the devastation.
A research scientist emphasizes the need to address climate change impacts.
